title: 107_hr287
content: The Act titled "Prompt Payment of Health Benefit Claims Act of 2001" establishes standards for prompt payment of health benefit claims by group health plans and health insurance issuers. This includes amendments to the Public Health Service Act to ensure timely payment of claims. The "Prompt Payment of Health Benefit Claims Act of 2001" mandates group health plans and health insurance issuers to pay claims within specific timeframes and accept clean claims meeting certain standards. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is amended to include a new section in Title I. SEC. 714. STANDARD RELATING TO PROMPT PAYMENT OF CLAIMS. A group health plan and health insurance issuer must pay claims within 15 business days for electronic submissions or 30 days for written claims. Clean claims must adhere to standards set by the Social Security Act. Section 732(a) of the Act is amended to include compliance with sections 711 and 714. The table of contents in section 1 of the Act is amended by adding a new item after section 713, inserting sections 711 and 714. Sec. 714 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new standard relating to prompt payment of claims (Sec. 9813). "A group health plan must pay claims within 15 business days for electronic submissions or 30 days for written claims. Clean claims must adhere to standards under the Social Security Act. A conforming amendment is made to Section 4980D(d)(1) of the Code." Individual Health Insurance provisions are added to Part B of title XXVII of the Public Health Service Act. SEC. 2753. STANDARD RELATING PATIENT FREEDOM OF CHOICE. The provisions of section 2707 apply to health insurance coverage in the individual market as they do in connection with a group health plan. Effective dates for group health plans start on or after January 1, 2002, while individual health insurance coverage starts on the specified date. The collective bargaining exception states that for group health plans under collective bargaining agreements ratified before the enactment of the Act, the amendments do not apply until the last agreement terminates or January 1, 2002. Amendments solely to comply with the Act do not count as termination. The Secretaries of Labor, Treasury, and Health and Human Services will coordinate to ensure regulations and enforcement policies related to the same matter are administered consistently and efficiently to avoid duplication of efforts. Section 1857(f)(1) of the Social Security Act is amended to include prompt payment to individuals enrolled through other lines of business. This amendment applies to contract years starting on or after January 1, 2002.
